article.paragraph: TheBoeing 767is a mid- to large-size,flight lengthlong-range,Wide-body aircraftwide-bodyTwinjettwin-enginejet airlinerbuilt byBoeing Commercial Airplanes. It was Boeing's first wide-bodytwinjetand its first airliner with a two-crewglass cockpit. The aircraft has twoturbofanengines, a conventionaltailplanetail, and, for reducedaerodynamic drag, asupercritical airfoilsupercritical wingdesign. Designed as a smaller wide-body airliner than earlier aircraft such as theBoeing 747747, the 767 has seating capacity for 181 to 375 persons and aRange (aeronautics)design rangeofConvert3850to6385nmikmin, depending on variant. Development of the 767 occurred in tandem with aNarrow-body aircraftnarrow-bodytwinjet, theBoeing 757757, resulting in shared design features which allow pilots to obtain a commontype ratingto operate both aircraft.

The 767 is produced in threefuselagelengths. The original 767-200 entered service in 1982, followed by the 767-300 in 1986 and the 767-400ER, an extended-range (ER) variant, in 2000. The extended-range 767-200ER and 767-300ER models entered service in 1984 and 1988, respectively, while a productionCargo aircraftfreighterversion, the 767-300F, debuted in 1995. Conversion programs have modified passenger 767-200 and 767-300 series aircraft for cargo use, while military derivatives include theBoeing E-767E-767Airborne early warning and controlsurveillanceaircraft, theBoeing KC-767KC-767andBoeing KC-46KC-46aerialaerial refuelingtankers, and VIP transports. Engines featured on the 767 include theGeneral Electric CF6,Pratt & Whitney JT9DandPratt & Whitney PW4000PW4000, andRolls-Royce RB211turbofans.

United Airlinesfirst placed the 767 in commercial service in 1982. The aircraft was initially flown on domestic andTranscontinental flight across the United Statestranscontinentalroutes, during which it demonstrated the reliability of its twinjet design. In 1985, the 767 became the first twin-engined airliner to receive regulatory approval for extended overseas flights. The aircraft was then used to expandNon-stop flightnon-stopservice onFlight lengthmedium- to long-haulintercontinental routes. In 1986, Boeing initiated studies for a higher-capacity 767, ultimately leading to the development of theBoeing 777777, a larger wide-body twinjet. In the 1990s, the 767 became the most frequently used airliner fortransatlantic flightsbetween North America and Europe.

The 767 is the first twinjet wide-body type to reach 1,000 aircraft delivered. As of July 2015, Boeing has received 1,161 orders for the 767 from 74 customers; 1,078 have been delivered. A total of 765 of these aircraft were in service in July 2015; the most popular variant is the 767-300ER, with 583 delivered;Delta Air Linesis the largest operator, with 95 aircraft. Competitors have included theAirbus A300,Airbus A310A310, andAirbus A330A330-200, while a successor, theBoeing 787 Dreamliner787 Dreamliner, entered service in October 2011.TOC limit3
article.heading: Development
Background
article.paragraph: In 1970, Boeing's 747 became the first wide-body jetliner to enter service.The 747 was the first passenger jet that was wide enough to feature a twin-aisle cabin.harvnbSutter2006103.Two years later, the manufacturer began a development study, code-named 7X7, for a new wide-body aircraft intended to replace theBoeing 707707and other early generation narrow-body jets.The aircraft would also provide twin-aisle seating, but in a smaller fuselage than the existing 747,McDonnell Douglas DC-10, andLockheed L-1011 TriStarwide-bodies.To defray the high cost of development, Boeing signed risk-sharing agreements with Italian corporationAeritaliaand the Civil Transport Development Corporation (CTDC), a consortium of Japanese aerospace companies.harvnbNorrisWagner1998156.This marked the manufacturer's first major international joint venture, and both Aeritalia and the CTDC received supply contracts in return for their early participation.The initial 7X7 was conceived as aSTOLshort take-off and landingairliner intended for short-distance flights, but customers were unenthusiastic about the concept, leading to its redefinition as a mid-size, transcontinental-range airliner.harvnbNorrisWagner1998156–57.At this stage the proposed aircraft featured two or three engines, with possible configurations including over-wing engines and aT-tail.harvnbEden2008102–03.

link.target: File:Delta Air Lines Boeing 767-232 Farnborough 1982 Fitzgerald.jpg
link.part: The 7X7 would make itsFarnborough Airshowdebut in 1982 as the 767-200.
alt=Side view of twin-engine jet touching down on runway, with deployed flaps and thrust reversers.

article.paragraph: By 1976, a twinjet layout, similar to the one which had debuted on theAirbus A300, became the baseline configuration.The decision to use two engines reflected increased industry confidence in the reliability and economics of new-generation jet powerplants.harvnbNorrisWagner199920–21.While airline requirements for new wide-body aircraft remained ambiguous,the 7X7 was generally focused on mid-size, high-density markets.As such, it was intended to transport large numbers of passengers between major cities.harvnbEden2008103.Advancements in civil aerospace technology, includinghigh-bypass turbofanhigh-bypass-ratio turbofanengines, new flight deck systems,aerodynamicimprovements, and lighter construction materials were to be applied to the 7X7.harvnbNorrisWagner199918–19.Many of these features were also included in a parallel development effort for a new mid-size narrow-body airliner, code-named 7N7, which would become the 757.Work on both proposals proceeded through the airline industry upturn in the late 1970s.harvnbDavies2000103.

In January 1978, Boeing announced a major extension of itsBoeing Everett FactoryEverett factorywhich was then dedicated to the manufacture of the 747to accommodate its new wide-body family.HarvnbBirtles19998.In February 1978, the new jetliner received the 767 model designation,HarvnbBecher199924.and three variants were planned: a 767-100 with 190 seats, a 767-200 with 210 seats, and atrijet767MR/LR version with 200 seats intended for intercontinental routes.harvnbDonald1997173.The 767MR/LR was subsequently renamed 777 for differentiation purposes.harvnbNorrisWagner1998159–60.The 767 was officially launched on July 14, 1978, when United Airlines ordered 30 of the 767-200 variant, followed by 50 more 767-200 orders fromAmerican Airlinesand Delta Air Lines later that year.The 767-100 was ultimately not offered for sale, as its capacity was too close to the 757's seating,while the 777 trijet was eventually dropped in favor of standardizing around the twinjet configuration.
article.heading: Design effort
article.paragraph: In the late 1970s,operating costreplaced capacity as the primary factor in airliner purchases.As a result, the 767's design process emphasizedfuel efficiencyfrom the outset.Boeing targeted a 20 to 30 percent cost saving over earlier aircraft, mainly through new engine and wing technology.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1981/1981%20-%202612.htmlBoeing 767: The new fuel saverAugust 8, 1981VelupillaiDavidFlight InternationalJuly 30, 2011436–37, 439, 440–41, 445–48, 453As development progressed, engineers usedcomputer-aided designfor over one-third of the 767's design drawings,and performed 26,000 hours ofwind tunneltests.Design work occurred concurrently with the 757 twinjet, leading Boeing to treat both as almost one program to reduce risk and cost.harvnbNorrisWagner1998143.Both aircraft would ultimately receive shared design features, includingavionics,flight management systems, instruments, and handling characteristics.Combined development costs were estimated at $3.5 to $4 billion.

link.part: Forward view of aContinental Airlines767-400ER, showing fuselage profile,Dihedral (aircraft)wing dihedral, andGeneral Electric CF6CF6engines
alt=Forward view of aircraft, showing fuselage profile, two circular engines.

article.paragraph: Early 767 customers were given the choice of Pratt & Whitney JT9D or General Electric CF6 turbofans, marking the first time that Boeing had offered more than one engine option at the launch of a new airliner.Both jet engine models had a maximum output ofconvert48000lbfkNofJet engine#Thrustthrust.The engines were mounted approximately one-third the length of the wing from the fuselage, similar to previous wide-body trijets.The larger wings were designed using ansupercritical airfoilaft-loadedshape which reduced aerodynamic drag and distributedlift (force)liftmore evenly across their surface span than any of the manufacturer's previous aircraft.The wings provided higher-altitudeCruise (flight)cruiseperformance, added fuel capacity, and expansion room for future stretched variants.The initial 767-200 was designed for sufficient range to fly across North America or across the northern Atlantic,harvnbSutter2006241–46.and would be capable of operating routes up toconvert3850nmikm.harvnbHaenggi200343–44.

The 767's fuselage width was set midway between that of the 707 and the 747 atconvert16.5ftm3.While it was narrower than previous wide-body designs, seven abreast seating with two aisles could be fitted, and the reduced width produced less aerodynamic drag.harvnbNorrisWagner199921–22.However, the fuselage was not wide enough to accommodate two standard LD3 wide-bodyunit load devicesside-by-side.harvnbHaenggi200329.HarvnbBirtles199914.As a result, a smaller container, the LD2,was created specifically for the 767.harvnbNorrisWagner1998158.The adoption of a conventional tail design also allowed the rear fuselage to be tapered over a shorter section,providing for parallel aisles along the full length of the passenger cabin, and eliminating irregular seat rows toward the rear of the aircraft.

link.part: alt=A cockpit of the 767-300ER, which exhibits a hybrid adoption of a new-generation instrument panel and analog gauges and indicators.

article.paragraph: The 767 was the first Boeing wide-body to be designed with a two-crew digital glass cockpit.harvnbNorrisWagner199923.Cathode ray tube(CRT) color displays and new electronics replaced the role of theflight engineerby enabling the pilot and co-pilot to monitor aircraft systems directly.Despite the promise of reduced crew costs, United Airlines initially demanded a conventional three-person cockpit, citing concerns about the risks associated with introducing a new aircraft.The carrier maintained this position until July 1981, when a U.S. presidential task force determined that a crew of two was safe for operating wide-body jets.cite webhttp://www.boeing.com/commercial/767family/pf/pf_fltdeck.htmlHistory of the 767 Two-Crew Flight DeckBoeingJuly 29, 2011HarvnbBecher199932.A three-crew cockpit remained as an option and was fitted to the first production models.HarvnbBecher199933.Ansett Australiaordered 767s with three-crew cockpits due to union demands; it was the only airline to operate 767s so configured.harvnbWilson2002117.The 767's two-crew cockpit was also applied to the 757, allowing pilots to operate both aircraft after a short conversion course,harvnbNorrisWagner1998160.and adding incentive for airlines to purchase both types.
article.heading: Production and testing
article.paragraph: To produce the 767, Boeing formed a network of subcontractors which included domestic suppliers and international contributions from Italy's Aeritalia and Japan's CTDC.The wings and cabin floor were produced in-house, while Aeritalia provided control surfaces,Boeing Rotorcraft SystemsBoeing Vertolmade theleading edgefor the wings, andSpirit AeroSystemsBoeing Wichitaproduced the forward fuselage.The CTDC provided multiple assemblies through its constituent companies, namelyFuji Heavy Industries(Aircraft fairingwing fairingsand gear doors),Kawasaki Heavy Industries(center fuselage), andMitsubishi Heavy Industries(rear fuselage, doors, and tail).Components were integrated during final assembly at the Everett factory.For expedited production of wingSpar (aviation)spars, the main structural member of aircraft wings, the Everett factory receivedroboticmachinery to automate the process of drilling holes and insertingfasteners.This method of wing construction expanded on techniques developed for the 747.Final assembly of the first aircraft began on July 6, 1979.

link.part: Final assembly of a 767-300F at Boeing'sBoeing Everett FactoryEverett factory, which was expanded for 767 production in 1978
alt=Airplane assembly hall, featuring an unpainted metallic twin-jet aircraft, a presentation podium, and arranged audience chairs.

article.paragraph: The prototype aircraft,aircraft registrationregisteredN767BA and equipped with JT9D turbofans, rolled out on August 4, 1981.harvnbShaw199964.By this time, the 767 program had accumulated 173 firm orders from 17 customers, includingAir Canada,All Nippon Airways,Britannia Airways,Transbrasil, andTrans World Airlines(TWA).On September 26, 1981, the prototype took itsmaiden flightunder the command of company test pilots Tommy Edmonds, Lew Wallick, and John Brit.The maiden flight was largely uneventful, save for the inability to retract thelanding gearowing to aHydraulicshydraulicfluid leak.The prototype was used for subsequent flight tests.

The 10-month 767 flight test program utilized the first six aircraft built.The first four aircraft were equipped with JT9D engines, while the fifth and sixth were fitted with CF6 engines.HarvnbBirtles199949–52.The test fleet was largely used to evaluate avionics, flight systems, handling, and performance,while the sixth aircraft was used for route-proving flights.During testing, pilots described the 767 as generally easy to fly, with its maneuverability unencumbered by the bulkiness associated with larger wide-body jets.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1982/1982%20-%200710.htmlBoeing tests the twinsSweetmanBillMarch 20, 1982Flight InternationalJuly 15, 2011Following the successful completion of 1,600 hours of flight tests, the JT9D-powered 767-200 received certification from the USFederal Aviation Administration(FAA) and the UKCivil Aviation Authority (United Kingdom)Civil Aviation Authority(CAA) in July 1982.harvnbNorrisWagner1998161–62.harvnbBirtles199916–18, 27.The first delivery occurred on August 19, 1982, to United Airlines.The CF6-powered 767-200 received certification in September 1982, followed by the first delivery to Delta Air Lines on October 25, 1982.
article.heading: Service entry and operations
article.paragraph: The 767 entered service with United Airlines on September 8, 1982.The aircraft's first commercial flight used a JT9D-powered 767-200 on the Chicago-to-Denver route.harvnbHaenggi200331–5.The CF6-powered 767-200 commenced service three months later with Delta Air Lines.Upon delivery, early 767s were mainly deployed on domestic routes, including U.S. transcontinental services.American Airlines and TWA began flying the 767-200 in late 1982, whileAir Canada,China Airlines, andEl Albegan operating the aircraft in 1983.HarvnbBirtles199955–58.The aircraft's introduction was relatively smooth, with few operational glitches and greaterDispatch (logistics)dispatchReliability engineeringreliabilitythan prior jetliners.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1983/1983%20-%200561.htmlBoeing 767 moves smoothly into serviceLynnNormanApril 2, 1983Flight InternationalJanuary 20, 2011In its first year, the 767 logged a 96.1 percent rate oftakeoffwithout delay due to technical issues, which exceeded the industry average for new aircraft.Operators reported generally favorable ratings for the twinjet's sound levels, interior comfort, and economic performance.Resolved issues were minor and included the recalibration of a leading edge sensor to prevent false readings, the replacement of anevacuation slidelatch, and the repair of atailplanepivot to match production specifications.

link.part: The firstnowrap767-200built, N767BA, in flight nearMount Rainierin the 1980s.
alt=Boeing twin engine jetliner in flight near a snow-capped mountain

article.paragraph: Seeking to capitalize on its new wide-body's potential for growth, Boeing offered an extended-range model, the 767-200ER, in its first year of service.harvnbNorrisWagner1998163.Ethiopian Airlinesplaced the first order for the type in December 1982.cite webhttp://www.boeing.com/commercial/767family/background.htmlBoeing 767 Program BackgroundBoeingJuly 30, 2011Featuring increasedgross weightspecifications and greater fuel capacity, the extended-range model could carry heavierPayload (air and space craft)payloadsat distances up toconvert6385nmikm,and was targeted at overseas customers.The 767-200ER entered service with El Al on March 27, 1984.The type was mainly ordered by international airlines operating medium-traffic, long-distance flights.

In the mid-1980s, the 767 spearheaded the growth of twinjet flights across the northern Atlantic under extended-range twin-engine operational performance standards (ETOPS) regulations, the FAA's safety rules governing transoceanic flights by aircraft with two engines.Before the 767, over-water flight paths of twinjets could be no more than 90 minutes away fromdiversion airports.harvnbHaenggi200338–40.In May 1985, the FAA granted its first approval for 120-minute ETOPS flights to 767 operators, on an individual airline basis starting with TWA, provided that the operator met flight safety criteria.This allowed the aircraft to fly overseas routes at up to two hours' distance from land.The larger safety margins were permitted because of the improved reliability demonstrated by the twinjet and its turbofan engines.The FAA lengthened the ETOPS time to 180 minutes for CF6-powered 767s in 1989, making the type the first to be certified under the longer duration,HarvnbBirtles199949–53.and all available engines received approval by 1993.HarvnbBecher1999150, 154–55.Regulatory approval spurred the expansion of transoceanic 767 flights and boosted the aircraft's sales.harvnbHaenggi200342.
article.heading: Stretched derivatives
article.paragraph: Forecasting airline interest in larger-capacity models, Boeing announced the stretched 767-300 in 1983 and the extended-range 767-300ER in 1984.Both models offered a 20 percent passenger capacity increase,while the extended-range version was capable of operating flights up toconvert5990nmikm.Japan Airlinesplaced the first order for the 767-300 in September 1983.Following its first flight on January 30, 1986,harvnbEden2008103–04.the type entered service with Japan Airlines on October 20, 1986.The 767-300ER completed its first flight on December 9, 1986,but it was not until March 1987 that the first firm order, from American Airlines, was placed.The type entered service with American Airlines on March 3, 1988.The 767-300 and 767-300ER gained popularity after entering service, and came to account for approximately two-thirds of all 767s sold.

After the debut of the first stretched 767s, Boeing sought to address airline requests for even more capacity by proposing larger models, including a partial double-deck version informally named the "Hunchback of Mukilteo" (from a town near Boeing's Everett factory) with a 757 body section mounted over the aft main fuselage.cite webhttps://web.archive.org/web/20090601173533/http://www.aiaa.org/sections/cl/what/mckinzie.htmJune 1, 2009http://www.aiaa.org/sections/cl/what/mckinzie.htmHow United Airlines Helped Design The World's Most Remarkable AirlinerAmerican Institute of Aeronautics and AstronauticsMcKinzieGordonJuly 1, 2011harvnbNorrisWagner200111–13, 15.In 1986, the manufacturer announced the 767-X, a revised model with extended wings and a wider cabin, but received little interest.By 1988, the 767-X had evolved into an all-new twinjet, which revived theBoeing 777777designation.Until the 777's 1995 debut, the 767-300 and 767-300ER remained Boeing's second-largest wide-bodies behind the 747.

link.target: File:Osaka KIX JAL 767-346 JA8986 and ANA 767-381ER JA612A.jpg
link.part: AJapan AirlinesJAL767-300 lands in front of anAll Nippon AirwaysANA767-300ER atKansai International AirportKansai Airport. The 300 and 300ER variants account for almost two-thirds of all 767s sold.
alt=A white and red-tailed Japan Airlines aircraft above runway, with landing gears down, and an All Nippon Airways in blue and white livery taxiing.

article.paragraph: Buoyed by a recovering global economy and ETOPS approval, 767 sales accelerated in the mid-to-late 1980s, with 1989 being the most prolific year with 132 firm orders.By the early 1990s, the wide-body twinjet had become its manufacturer's annual best-selling aircraft, despite a slight decrease due to economic recession.During this period, the 767 became the most common airliner for transatlantic flights between North America and Europe.harvnbSmil199828.By the end of the decade, 767s crossed the Atlantic more frequently than all other aircraft types combined.harvnbDavies200088–89.The 767 also propelled the growth ofPoint-to-point transitpoint-to-pointflights which bypassed majorairline hubsin favor ofdirect flightdirect routes.harvnbNorrisWagner200912.Taking advantage of the aircraft's lower operating costs and smaller capacity, operators added non-stop flights to secondary population centers, thereby eliminating the need for connecting flights.The increase in the number of cities receiving non-stop services caused a paradigm shift in the airline industry as point-to-point travel gained prominence at the expense of the traditionalSpoke-hub distribution paradigmhub-and-spokemodel.

In February 1990, the first 767 equipped withRolls-Royce RB211turbofans, a 767-300, was delivered toBritish Airways.HarvnbBirtles199927–28.Six months later, the carrier temporarily grounded its entire 767 fleet after discovering cracks in thehardpointengine pylonsof several aircraft.HarvnbBirtles199964.The cracks were related to the extra weight of the RB211 engines, which areconvert2205lbkgheavier than other 767 engines.During the grounding, interim repairs were conducted to alleviate stress on engine pylon components, and a parts redesign in 1991 prevented further cracks.Boeing also performed a structural reassessment, resulting in production changes and modifications to the engine pylons of all 767s in service.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/boeing-acts-to-solve-757767-pylon-cracks-25909/Boeing acts to solve 757/767 pylon cracksGuyNorrisFlight InternationalMay 24, 1995December 26, 2011

link.part: The Boeing 767-400ER was publicly unveiled on August 26, 1999.
alt=Side quarter view of twin-engine jetliner in front of hangar, with surrounding crowds.

article.paragraph: In January 1993, following an order fromUPS Airlines,harvnbEden2008105.Boeing launched a freighter variant, the 767-300F, which entered service with UPS on October 16, 1995.The 767-300F featured a main deck cargo hold, upgraded landing gear, and strengthened wing structure.In November 1993, the Japanese government launched the first 767 military derivative when it placed orders for thenowrapE-767, anAirborne Early Warning and Control(AWACS) variant based on the 767-200ER.The first twonowrapE-767s, featuring extensive modifications to accommodate surveillanceradarand other monitoring equipment, were delivered in 1998 to theJapan Self-Defense Forces.

In November 1995, after abandoning development of a smaller version of the 777, Boeing announced that it was revisiting studies for a larger 767.HarvnbBecher1999125.The proposed 767-400X, a second stretch of the aircraft, offered an over 12 percent capacity increase versus the 767-300,and featured an upgraded flight deck, enhanced interior, and wider wingspan.harvnbNorrisWagner1999116–21.The variant was specifically aimed at Delta Air Lines' pending replacement of its aging Lockheed L-1011 TriStars, and faced competition from the A330-200, a shortened derivative of the Airbus A330.In March 1997, Delta Air Lines launched the 767-400ER when it ordered the type to replace its L-1011 fleet.In October 1997,Continental Airlinesalso ordered the 767-400ER to replace its McDonnell Douglas DC-10 fleet.HarvnbBirtles199940.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/continental-goes-boeing-13833/Continental goes BoeingRamonLopezFlight InternationalJune 18, 1997December 28, 2011The type completed its first flight on October 9, 1999, and entered service with Continental Airlines on September 14, 2000.
article.heading: Further developments

link.part: Austrian Airlines767-300ER with blendedwinglets, which reducelift-induced dragand improve fuel efficiency
alt=Rear quarter view of an Austrian Airlines 767 takeoff, with red winglets.

article.paragraph: In the early 2000s, cumulative 767 deliveries approached 900, but new sales declined during an airline industry downturn.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2003/04/01/163582/long-players.htmlLong playersJanuary 4, 2003Flight InternationalGuyNorrisKingsley-Jones, MaxJuly 30, 2011In 2001, Boeing dropped plans for a longer-range model, the 767-400ERX, in favor of the proposedBoeing Sonic CruiserSonic Cruiser, a new jetliner which aimed to fly 15 percent faster while having comparable fuel costs as the 767.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/2001/2001%20-%201119.htmlBoeing Sonic Cruiser Ousts 747XApril 3, 2001Flight InternationalGuyNorrisKelly, EmmaAugust 15, 2011cite journalSonic Cruiser seeks mission definitionJuly 2001Interavia Business & Technology5665525http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P3-77659773.htmlJune 30, 2015[[HighBeam]]yesThe following year, the manufacturer announced theBoeing KC-767#International programsKC-767 Tanker Transport, a second military derivative of the 767-200ER.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2006/07/11/207660/pumped-for-action.htmlPumped for actionNovember 7, 2006Flight InternationalGuyNorrisAugust 30, 2011Launched with an order in October 2002 from theItalian Air Force, the KC-767 was intended for the dual role of refueling other aircraft and carrying cargo.The Japanese government became the second customer for the type in March 2003.In May 2003, theUnited States Air Force(USAF) announced its intent to lease KC-767s to replace its agingBoeing KC-135 StratotankerKC-135tankers.cite webhttp://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/02/24/usa-tanker-idUKN2315169720110224Pentagon nears new contract in air tanker sagaReutersShalal-EsaAndreaFebruary 24, 2010December 26, 2011McCarthy, John; Price, Wayne. (March 9, 2010). "Northrop pulls out of tanker bidding war."Florida Today,p. A1.The plan was suspended in March 2004 amid aconflict of interestBoeing KC-767#USAF lease and cancellationscandal,resulting in multiple U.S. government investigations and the departure of several Boeing officials, includingPhilip M. ConditPhilip Condit, the company'schief executive officer, andchief financial officerMichael Sears.cite webhttp://www.seattlepi.com/business/article/Stalled-767-deal-may-cost-jobs-1137579.php#page-1Stalled 767 deal may cost jobsSeattle Post-IntelligencerFebruary 20, 2004WallaceJamesDecember 26, 2011The first KC-767s were delivered in 2008 to the Japan Self-Defense Forces.

In late 2002, after airlines expressed reservations about its emphasis on speed over cost reduction,Boeing halted development of the Sonic Cruiser.harvnbNorrisWagner200932–35.The following year, the manufacturer announced the 7E7, a mid-size 767 successor made fromcomposite materialswhich promised to be 20 percent more fuel efficient.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2007/07/07/209212/everything-about-the-boeing-787-dreamliner.htmlBoeing 787 Dreamliner Aircraft ProfileFlight International2011July 30, 2011The new jetliner was the first stage of a replacement aircraft initiative called theBoeing Yellowstone Project.Customers embraced the 7E7, later renamed 787 Dreamliner, and within two years it had become the fastest-selling airliner in the company's history.In 2005, Boeing opted to continue 767 production despite record Dreamliner sales, citing a need to provide customers waiting for the 787 with a more readily available option.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2005/06/21/199772/767-earns-reprieve-as-787-ramp-up-considered.html767 earns reprieve as 787 ramp-up consideredFlight InternationalJune 5, 2005July 30, 2011Subsequently, the 767-300ER was offered to customers affected by 787 delays, including All Nippon Airways and Japan Airlines.cite webJAL to take 11 767s and 777s in 787-delay compensation dealNicholesIonidesFlight InternationalSeptember 17, 2008http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2008/09/17/316096/jal-to-take-11-767s-and-777s-in-787-delay-compensation.htmlSeptember 15, 2011Some aging 767s, exceeding 20 years in age, were also kept in service past planned retirement dates due to the delays.cite webhttp://www.heraldsun.com.au/businessold/ageing-jets-to-fly-on-due-to-delay-in-boeing-dreamliner/story-e6frfh4f-1225991529905Ageing jets to fly on due to delay in Boeing DreamlinerHerald SunJanuary 19, 2011September 9, 2011To extend the operational lives of older aircraft, airlines increased heavy maintenance procedures, includingAircraft maintenance checksD-checkteardowns and inspections forcorrosion, a recurring issue on aging 767s.cite webhttp://www.timco.aero/content/articles/checking-767-mro-management.htmlChecking Up on the 767IanGooldMRO ManagementJune 20102015-07-03https://web.archive.org/web/20120426072500/http://www.timco.aero/content/articles/checking-767-mro-management.html2012-04-26yesThe first 787s would ultimately enter service with All Nippon Airways in October 2011, three-and-a-half years behind schedule.cite webhttp://atwonline.com/aircraft-engines-components/news/finally-787-enters-service-1026Finally ... the 787 enters serviceKarenWalkerAir Transport WorldOctober 27, 2011December 9, 2011

File:UPS 767.jpgthumbUPS AirlinesUPS, the largest 767-300F operator, placed additional orders in 2007.alt=Side quarter view of UPS twin-engine freighter in flight, with extended gear.In 2007, the 767 received a production boost when UPS andDHL Aviationplaced a combined 33 orders for the 767-300F.cite webhttp://www.seattlepi.com/business/article/UPS-order-revives-767-line-1227427.phpUPS order revives 767 lineSeattle Post-IntelligencerFebruary 5, 2007August 19, 2011cite webhttp://www.marketwatch.com/story/dhl-orders-6-boeing-767-freightersDHL orders 6 Boeing 767 freightersMarketWatchPadraicCassidyMarch 8, 2007August 19, 2011Renewed freighter interest led Boeing to consider enhanced versions of the 767-200 and 767-300F with increased gross weights, 767-400ER wing extensions, and 777 avionics.cite webhttp://atwonline.com/aircraftenginescomponents/news/boeing-considering-new-767-freighter-counter-a330-200f-0309Boeing considering new 767 freighter to counter A330-200FAviation Week & Space TechnologyGeoffreyThomasMarch 2, 2007July 29, 2011However, net orders for the 767 declined from 24 in 2008 to just three in 2010.cite webhttp://active.boeing.com/commercial/orders/index.cfm?contentBoeing Company Annual Orders SummaryBoeingJanuary 23, 2011During the same period, operators upgraded aircraft already in service; in 2008, the first 767-300ER retrofitted with blendedWingtip devicewingletsfromAviation Partners Inc.Aviation Partners Incorporateddebuted with American Airlines.The manufacturer-sanctioned winglets, atconvert11ftm3in height, improved fuel efficiency by an estimated 6.5 percent.Cite journalRansonLorihttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2008/07/22/225951/blended-winglets-debut-on-boeing-767.htmlBlended winglets debut on Boeing 767Flight InternationalJuly 22, 2008August 19, 2011Other carriers including All Nippon Airways and Delta Air Lines also ordered winglet kits.Cite journalYeoGhim-Layhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/07/23/344919/farnborough-hainan-and-ana-to-equip-boeing-aircraft-with.htmlFarnborough: Hainan and ANA to equip Boeing aircraft with wingletsFlight Daily NewsJuly 23, 2010August 19, 2011cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2007/06/20/214967/delta-takes-tips-from-aviation-partners.htmlDelta takes tips from Aviation PartnersFlight Daily NewsJune 20, 2007August 19, 2011

On February 2, 2011, the 1,000th 767 rolled out, destined for All Nippon Airways.The aircraft was the 91st 767-300ER ordered by the Japanese carrier, and with its completion the 767 became the second wide-body airliner to reach the thousand-unit milestone after the 747.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2011/02/03/352770/picture-boeing-unveils-1000th-767.htmlBoeing unveils 1,000th 767Ostrower, Jon.Air Transport IntelligenceFebruary 3, 2011February 6, 2011cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2011/01/12/351792/thousandth-767-etches-twinjets-place-in-history.htmlThousandth 767 etches twinjet's place in historyDecember 1, 2010Flight InternationalJanuary 20, 2011The 1,000th aircraft also marked the last model produced on the original 767 assembly line.Beginning with the 1,001st aircraft, production moved to another area in the Everett factory which occupied nearly half the space as before.The new assembly line made room for 787 production and aimed to boost manufacturing efficiency by over 20 percent.

At the inauguration of its new assembly line, the 767's order backlog numbered approximately 50, only enough for production to last until 2013.cite webhttp://www.heraldnet.com/article/20110306/BIZ/703069951/1122/news01767 now built faster and in less spaceMichelleDunlopThe Weekly HeraldMarch 6, 2011July 30, 2011Despite the reduced backlog, Boeing officials expressed optimism that additional orders were forthcoming.On February 24, 2011, the USAF announced its selection of the KC-767 Advanced Tanker, an upgraded variant of the KC-767,cite webhttp://www.upi.com/Business_News/Security-Industry/2008/01/03/Boeing-presents-KC-767-proposal-to-USAF/UPI-86481199401085/Boeing presents KC-767 proposal to USAFUnited Press InternationalJanuary 3, 2008December 26, 2011for itsKC-Xfleet renewal program.The selection followed two rounds of tanker competition between Boeing andAirbusparentEADS, and came eight years after the USAF's original 2003 announcement of its plan to lease KC-767s.The tanker order encompassed 179 aircraft and was expected to sustain 767 production past 2013.

In December 2011,FedEx Expressannounced a 767-300F order for 27 aircraft to replace its DC-10 freighters, citing the USAF tanker order and Boeing's decision to continue production as contributing factors.cite webhttp://www.thestreet.com/story/11350825/2/boeing-767-removed-from-life-support.htmlBoeing 767 Removed From Life SupportThe StreetTedReedDecember 20, 2011December 26, 2011FedEx Express announced an agreement to buy an additional 19 of the 300F variant in June 2012.cite webFedEx Express Plans to Acquire 19 Boeing 767-300F Aircraft and Convert Four 777 Freighter Ordershttp://news.van.fedex.com/node/18533FedEx Express press releaseJune 29, 2012July 2, 2012cite newsAssociated PressFedEx to buy additional aircraft from Boeinghttp://www.businessweek.com/ap/2012-06-29/fedex-to-buy-additional-aircraft-from-boeingBusinessweekJune 29, 20122015-07-03https://web.archive.org/web/20120703070730/http://www.businessweek.com/ap/2012-06-29/fedex-to-buy-additional-aircraft-from-boeing2012-07-03yesIn June 2015, FedEx said it was accelerating retirements of planes both to reflect demand and to modernize its fleet, recording charges of $276 million.cite newshttp://www.wsj.com/articles/fedex-to-buy-as-many-as-100-boeing-767-freighters-1437522505FedEx to Buy as Many as 100 Boeing 767 FreightersThe Wall Street Journal21 July 201521 July 2015On July 21, 2015 FedEx announced an order for 50 767-300F with options on another 50, the largest order for the type.http://www.streetinsider.com/Corporate+News/FedEx+Express+%28FDX%29+Will+Acquire+Addtional+50+Boeing+%28BA%29+767-300F+Aircraft/10739876.htmlFedEx confirmed that it has firm orders for 106 of the freighters for delivery between 2018 and 2023.
article.heading: Design
Overview

link.part: The nose assembly of a Boeing 767, also known as fuselage section 41
alt=Close up view of a green Section 41, the nose section of a 767. Installation is not yet complete for the window panes.

article.paragraph: The 767 is a low-wingCantilever#Aircraftcantilever monoplanewith a conventional tail unit featuring a single fin and rudder. The wings are swept at 31.5 degrees and optimized for a cruising speed ofMach numberMach0.8 (convert533mphkm/h3onor).Each wing features a supercritical cross-section and is equipped with six-panelleading edge slats, single- and double-slottedFlap (aircraft)flaps, inboard and outboardailerons, and sixSpoiler (aeronautics)spoilers.HarvnbBirtles199915–16.Theairframefurther incorporatesCarbon-fiber-reinforced polymercomposite materialwing surfaces,KevlarAircraft fairingfairingsand access panels, plus improvedaluminium alloyaluminum alloys, which together reduce overall weight byconvert1900lbkgversus preceding aircraft.

To distribute the aircraft's weight on the ground, the 767 has a retractableTricycle geartricycle landing gearwith four wheels on each main gear and two for the nose gear.The original wing and gear design accommodated the stretched 767-300 without major changes.The 767-400ER features a larger, more widely spaced main gear with 777 wheels, tires, and brakes.harvnbNorrisWagner1999119, 121.To prevent damage if the tail section contacts the runway surface during takeoff, 767-300 and 767-400ER models are fitted with a retractabletailstriketailskid.cite webhttp://www.boeing.com/news/frontiers/archive/2004/december/i_tt.htmlStriking out tailstrikesKatherineSopranosFrontiersDecember 2004August 21, 2012The 767 has exit doors near the front and rear of the aircraft on the left side.

In addition to shared avionics and computer technology, the 767 uses the sameauxiliary power unit, electric power systems, and hydraulic parts as the 757.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1982/1982%20-%200014.htmlBoeing 757: introducing the big-fan narrowbodyJanuary 2, 1983VelupillaiDavidFlight InternationalFebruary 2, 2011A raised cockpit floor and the same forward cockpit windows result in similar pilot viewing angles.harvnbNorrisWagner199669.Related design and functionality allows 767 pilots to obtain a commontype ratingto operate the 757 and share the sameseniorityroster with pilots of either aircraft.harvnbWellsClarence2004252.
article.heading: Flight systems

link.part: The upgraded 767-400ER cockpit usesLiquid crystal displayLCDsin place ofCathode ray tubeCRTdisplays.
alt=A cockpit of the 767, with multiple liquid crystal display monitors.

article.paragraph: The original 767 flight deck uses sixRockwell CollinsCRT screens to displayElectronic flight instrument system(EFIS) andElectronic flight instrument system#Engine indications and crew alerting system (EICAS) / electronic centralized aircraft monitoring (ECAM)engine indication and crew alerting system(EICAS) information, allowing pilots to handle monitoring tasks previously performed by the flight engineer.harvnbBirtles199920, 25.The CRTs replace conventionalelectromechanicselectromechanicalinstruments found on earlier aircraft.An enhanced flight management system, improved over versions used on early 747s,automates navigation and other functions, while anAutolandautomatic landingsystem facilitatesInstrument landing systemCAT IIIbinstrument landings in low visibility situations.Young, David (June 17, 1982). "767's maiden O'Hare landing is automatic".Chicago Tribune, p. 3.The 767 became the first aircraft to receive CAT IIIb certification from the FAA for landings withconvert980ftmusminimum visibility in 1984.cite webhttp://fsims.faa.gov/wdocs/8900.1/v04%20ac%20equip%20&%20auth/chapter%2002/04_002_001.htmFAA Order 8900.1 Flight Standards Information Management System (FSIMS), Volume 4 Aircraft Equipment and Operational AuthorizationsFederal Aviation AdministrationSeptember 13, 2007July 29, 2011RVR 300, Runway Visual Range 300 meters.On the 767-400ER, the cockpit layout is simplified further with six Rockwell Collinsliquid crystal display(LCD) screens, and adapted for similarities with the 777 and theBoeing 737 Next GenerationNext Generation 737.harvnbNorrisWagner1999117.To retain operationalcommonality, the LCD screens can be programmed to display information in the same manner as earlier 767s.In 2012, Boeing and Rockwell Collins launched a further 787-based cockpit upgrade for the 767, featuring three landscape-format LCD screens that can display two windows each.cite webhttp://www.aviationweek.com/Blogs.aspx?plckPostIdBoeing's KC-46A Tanker Sparks 767 Cockpit UpgradeGrahamWarwickAviation Week & Space TechnologyJuly 10, 20122015-07-04https://web.archive.org/web/20140221221440/http://www.aviationweek.com/Blogs.aspx?plckPostId2014-02-21yes

The 767 is equipped with three redundant hydraulic systems for operation of control surfaces, landing gear, and other equipment.Each engine powers a separate hydraulic system, and the third system uses electric pumps.harvnbBirtles199924.Aram air turbineis fitted to provide power for basic controls in the event of an emergency.harvnbBirtles199950.An early form offly-by-wireis employed for spoiler operation, utilizing electric signaling instead of traditional control cables.The fly-by-wire system reduces weight and provides for the independent operation of individual spoilers.
article.heading: Interior
article.paragraph: The 767 features a twin-aisle cabin with a typical configuration of six abreast inbusiness classand seven across ineconomy classeconomy.The standard seven abreast, 232 economy class layout places approximately 87 percent of all seats at a window or aisle.harvnbKane2003553.As a result, the aircraft can be largely occupied before center seats need to be filled,and each passenger is no more than one seat from the aisle.It is possible to configure the aircraft with extra seats for up to an eight abreast configuration,but this results in a cramped cabin and is therefore uncommon.harvnbHaenggi200334.

template.arg: Cabin of the 767. There are seven seats per row, with two aisles separating the seats. Light shines through the side-wall windows and overhead lighting.
An early 767-300 [[economy class]] cabin in 2–3–2 layout, showing the original interior design
A newer 767-300ER cabin with the [[Boeing 777|777]]-style Signature Interior
Airliner cabin. Rows of seats arranged between two aisles. Each seatback has a monitor; additional monitors hang from ceiling.

article.paragraph: The 767 interior introduced largerAirliner#Overhead binsoverhead binsand more lavatories per passenger than previous aircraft.The bins are wider to accommodategarment bagswithout folding, and strengthened for heavier carry-on items.cite webhttp://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?resHow Airline Cabins are being ReshapedThe New York TimesMay 24, 1981PaceEricFebruary 1, 2011A single, largeGalley (kitchen)galleyis installed near the aft doors, allowing for more efficient meal service and simpler resupply while at airports.Passenger and service doors are an overheadPlug doorplugtype, which retract upwards,and commonly used doors can be equipped with anelectric motorelectric-assistsystem.

In 2000, a 777-style interior, known as the Boeing Signature Interior, debuted on the 767-400ER.cite webhttp://www.boeing.com/news/frontiers/archive/2003/april/i_ca2.htmlBoeing Signature Interior a hit with flying publicFrontiersDavis, ElizabethApril 2003August 19, 2011Subsequently adopted for all new-build 767s, the Signature Interior features even larger overhead bins, indirect lighting, and sculpted, curved panels.harvnbNorrisWagner1999122.The 767-400ER also received larger windows derived from the 777.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/2000/2000-1%20-%200316.htmlStretching and TestingGuyNorrisFlight InternationalAugust 19, 2011July 24, 2000Older 767s can be retrofitted with the Signature Interior.Some operators have adopted a simpler modification known as the Enhanced Interior, featuring curved ceiling panels and indirect lighting with minimal modification of cabin architecture,cite webhttp://boeing.mediaroom.com/2005-03-09-Thomsonfly.com-Launches-Enhanced-Interior-Package-for-Boeing-757-200-and-767-200Thomsonfly.com Launches Enhanced Interior Package for Boeing 757-200 and 767-200BoeingMarch 9, 20052015-07-04as well as aftermarket modifications such as the NuLook 767 package by Heath Tecna.cite webhttp://www.heath.com/Capabilities/Product-Showcase/B767-IUS/Description.aspxB767 Interior Upgrade SystemsHeath TecnaAugust 18, 2011clear
article.heading: Variants

link.part: alt=Underside view of a jet in-flight. Each wing of the two wings have an engine. Towards the left are the horizontal stabilizers.

article.paragraph: The 767 has been produced in three fuselage lengths.These debuted in progressively larger form as the 767-200, 767-300, and 767-400ER, respectively.harvnbEden2008104–05.Longer-range variants include the 767-200ER and 767-300ER,while cargo models include the 767-300F, a production freighter,and conversions of passenger 767-200 and 767-300 models.

When referring to different variants, Boeing and airlines often collapse the model number (767) and the variant designator (e.g. 200 or 300) into a truncated form (e.g. "762" or "763"cite webhttp://www.aa.com/i18n/aboutUs/ourPlanes/ourPlanes.jspOur PlanesAmerican Airlines2011August 28, 2011). Subsequent to the capacity number, designations may or may not append the range identifier.cite webhttp://www.continental.com/web/en-US/content/travel/inflight/aircraft/762.aspxBoeing 767-200ERContinental Airlines20112015-07-04https://web.archive.org/web/20110805082240/http://www.continental.com/web/en-US/content/travel/inflight/aircraft/762.aspx2011-08-05yesTheInternational Civil Aviation Organization(ICAO) aircraft type designator system uses a similar numbering scheme, but adds a preceding manufacturer letter;all variants based on the 767-200 and 767-300 are classified under the codes "B762" and "B763", respectively, while the 767-400ER receives the designation of "B764."cite webhttp://www.icao.int/publications/DOC8643/ICAO Document 8643International Civil Aviation OrganizationDecember 10, 2011

The 767-200 was the original model and entered service withUnited Airlinesin 1982.The type has been used primarily byMainline (flight)mainlineU.S. carriers for domestic routes between major hub centers such as Los Angeles to Washington.The 767-200 was the first aircraft to be used on transatlanticETOPSflights, beginning with TWA on February 1, 1985 under 90-minute diversion rules.Deliveries for the variant totaled 128 aircraft.There were 49 passenger and freighter conversions of the model in commercial service as of July 2015.The type's competitors included the Airbus A300 and A310.HarvnbBecher1999175.

The 767-200 ceased production in the late 1980s due to being superseded by the extended-range 767-200ER.Some early 767-200s were subsequently upgraded to extended-range specification.In 1998, Boeing began offering 767-200 conversions to 767-200SF (Special Freighter) specification for cargo use,cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/boeing-enters-ups-bidding-with-767-special-freighter-36199/Boeing enters UPS bidding with 767 'Special Freighter'GuyNorrisFlight InternationalApril 22, 1998December 28, 2011andIsrael Aerospace Industrieshas been licensed to perform cargo conversions since 2005.cite webhttp://easa.europa.eu/certification/type-certificates/docs/supplemental/EASA-TCDS-AS.00632_(IM)_IAI_B767--200SF_(Special_Freighter_Conversion)-03-23022011.pdfSupplemental Type-Certificate Data SheetEuropean Aviation Safety AgencyFebruary 23, 2011August 18, 20114The conversion process entails the installation of a side cargo door, strengthened main deck floor, and added freight monitoring and safety equipment.cite webhttp://rgl.faa.gov/Regulatory_and_Guidance_Library/rgMakeModel.nsf/0/05d3a0b75a0d480086257847004ffb2f/$FILE/A1NM%20Rev%2030.pdfFederal Aviation AdministrationMarch 4, 2011Federal Aviation Administration Type Certificate Data Sheet A1NMDecember 26, 20116–8The 767-200SF is positioned as a replacement forDouglas DC-8freighters.
article.heading: 767-2C
article.paragraph: mainBoeing KC-46 PegasusA commercial freighter version of the Boeing 767-200 with series 300 wings and an updated flightdeck was first flown on 29 December 2014.citationTrimbleStephenhttp://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/boeing-completes-first-flight-of-new-freighter-and-tanker-407472/Boeing completes first flight of new freighter and tanker[[Flightglobal]]Reed Business Information28 December 201430 December 2014https://web.archive.org/web/20141230230129/http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/boeing-completes-first-flight-of-new-freighter-and-tanker-407472/30 December 2014noA military tanker variant of the Boeing 767-2C is being developed for the United States Air Force as the KC-46.Boeing is building two aircraft as commercial freighters which will be used to obtain Federal Aviation Administration certification, a further two Boeing 767-2Cs will be modified as military tankers.asof2014, Boeing does not have customers for the freighter.
article.heading: 767-200ER

link.part: AnAmerican Airlines767-200ER departingLos Angeles International Airport

alt=Sideview of 767 on climbout against a pale blue sky. A blue, white and red cheat-line runs the full length of the fuselage, above which says "American". The vertical tail sports two "A"s, between which is a simplified eagle.

article.paragraph: The 767-200ER was the first extended-range model and entered service withEl Alin 1984.The type's increased range is due to an additional center fuel tank and a highermaximum takeoff weight(MTOW) of up toconvert395000lbkg3.The type was originally offered with the same engines as the 767-200, while more powerful Pratt & Whitney PW4000 and General Electric CF6 engines later became available.The 767-200ER was the first 767 to complete a non-stop transatlantic journey, and broke the flying distance record for a twinjet airliner on April 17, 1988 with anAir Mauritiusflight from Halifax, Nova Scotia to Port Louis, Mauritius, covering a distance ofconvert8727nmikm.The 767-200ER has been acquired by international operators seeking smaller wide-body aircraft for long-haul routes such as New York to Beijing.Deliveries of the type totaled 121 with no unfilled orders.As of July 2015, 35 examples of passenger and freighter conversion versions were in airline service.The type's competitors included the Airbus A300-600R and the A310-300.

The 767-300, the first stretched version of the aircraft, entered service with Japan Airlines in 1986.The type features aconvert21.1ftm3onfuselage extension over the 767-200, achieved by additional sections inserted before and after the wings, for an overall length ofconvert180.25ftm3.Reflecting the growth potential built into the original 767 design, the wings, engines, and most systems were largely unchanged on the 767-300.An optional mid-cabin exit door is positioned ahead of the wings on the left,while more powerful Pratt & Whitney PW4000 and Rolls-Royce RB211 engines later became available.The 767-300's increased capacity has been used on high-density routes within Asia and Europe.HarvnbBirtles199962, 90–95.Deliveries for the type totaled 104 aircraft with no unfilled orders remaining.As of July 2015, 67 of the variant were in airline service.The type's main competitor was the Airbus A300.
article.heading: 767-300ER

link.part: AUnited Airlines767-300ER arriving atMinistro Pistarini International AirportEzeiza International Airportin the old livery
alt=Side quarter view of twin-engine jetliner in flight, with extended gear; white with blue stripes paint scheme.

article.paragraph: The 767-300ER, the extended-range version of the 767-300, entered service with American Airlines in 1988.The type's increased range was made possible by greater fuel tankage and a higher MTOW ofconvert407000lbkg3.Design improvements allowed the available MTOW to increase toconvert412000lbkg3by 1993.Power is provided by Pratt & Whitney PW4000, General Electric CF6, or Rolls-Royce RB211 engines.Typical routes for the type includeLos Angeles International AirportLos AngelestoFrankfurt AirportFrankfurt.The combination of increased capacity and range offered by the 767-300ER has been particularly attractive to both new and existing 767 operators.It is the most successful version of the aircraft, with more orders placed than all other variants combined.harvnbHaenggi200343.As of August 2015, 767-300ER deliveries stand at 583 with no unfilled orders.There were 467 examples in service as of July 2015.The type's main competitor is the Airbus A330-200.cite webAirbus A330-200Flug RevueJuly 18, 2000http://www.flug-revue.rotor.com/frtypen/FRA33020.htmAugust 18, 2011December 26, 2004https://web.archive.org/web/20010218184251/http://www.flug-revue.rotor.com/frtypen/FRA33020.htm
article.heading: 767-300F
article.paragraph: The 767-300F, the production freighter version of the 767-300ER, entered service with UPS Airlines in 1995.HarvnbBecher1999178.The 767-300F can hold up to 24 standardconvert88by125inonpalletson its main deck and up to 30 LD2 unit load devices on the lower deck,with a total cargo volume ofconvert15469cuft3.The freighter has a main deck cargo door and crew exit,harvnbKane2003555.while the lower deck features two port-side cargo doors and one starboard cargo door.A general market version with onboard freight-handling systems,refrigerationcapability, and crew facilities was delivered toAsiana Airlineson August 23, 1996.As of September 2015, 767-300F deliveries stand at 107 with 77 unfilled orders.Airlines operated 115 examples of the freighter variant and freighter conversions in July 2015.

In June 2008, All Nippon Airways took delivery of the first 767-300BCF (Boeing Converted Freighter), a modified passenger-to-freighter model.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2008/06/16/224718/st-aero-delivers-worlds-first-767-300bcf-to-all-nippon.htmlST Aero delivers world's first 767-300BCF to All Nippon AirwaysLeithenFrancisFlight InternationalJune 16, 2008August 19, 2011The conversion work was performed in Singapore byST Aerospace#Subsidiaries/DivisionsST Aerospace Services, the first supplier to offer a 767-300BCF program,and involved the addition of a main deck cargo door, strengthened main deck floor, and additional freight monitoring and safety equipment.Since then, Boeing, Israel Aerospace Industries, and Wagner Aeronautical have also offered passenger-to-freighter conversion programs for 767-300 series aircraft.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/10/21/348813/wagner-plans-to-launch-767-cargo-conversion-programme.htmlWagner plans to launch 767 cargo conversion programmeAir Transport IntelligenceSobie, BrendanOctober 21, 2010October 31, 2010
article.heading: 767-400ER
article.paragraph: [[File:Delta Air Lines 767-400ER N845MH MAC EGLL 29.05.11.jpg|thumb|right|ADelta Air Lines767-400ER in pinkThe Breast Cancer Research FoundationBreast Cancer Research Foundationlivery landing atLondon Heathrow Airport|alt= Twin-engine airliner with white and pink colors on approach with landing gear and flaps extended.]]

The 767-400ER, the first Boeing wide-body jet resulting from two fuselage stretches,harvnbNorrisWagner1999114.entered service with Continental Airlines in 2000.The type features aconvert21.1ftmoff3onstretch over the 767-300, for a total length ofconvert201.25ftm3.harvnbNorrisWagner1999120.The wingspan is also increased byconvert14.3ftm3through the addition ofraked wingtips.Other differences include an updated cockpit, redesigned landing gear, and 777-style Signature Interior.harvnbNorrisWagner1999119–120, 123.Power is provided by uprated Pratt & Whitney PW4000 or General Electric CF6 engines.

The FAA granted approval for the 767-400ER to operate 180-minuteETOPSflights before it entered service.cite webBoeing 767-400ER gets FAA clearanceFlight Internationalhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2000/07/25/68337/boeing-767-400er-gets-faa-clearance.htmlJuly 25, 2000February 1, 2011Because its fuel capacity was not increased over preceding models, the 767-400ER has a range ofconvert5625nmikm,less than previous extended-range 767s.This is roughly the distance from London to Tokyo.cite webhttp://www.gcmap.com/dist?PGreat Circle MapperGcmap.com2013-06-02No 767-400 version was developed, while a longer-range version, the 767-400ERX, was offered for sale in 2000 before it was cancelled a year later,leaving the 767-400ER as the sole version of the largest 767.harvnbFrawley200163.A total of 37 aircraft were delivered to the variant's two airline customers,Continental Airlines(now merged withUnited Airlines) andDelta Air Lines, with no unfilled orders.All 37 examples of the -400ER were in service in July 2015.One additional example was produced as a military testbed, and later sold as a VIP transport.Cite journalSarsfieldKatehttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/01/27/321681/bahrain-acquires-767-400er-testbed-for-vip-use.htmlBahrain acquires 767-400ER testbed for VIP useFlight InternationalJanuary 27, 2009January 21, 2011The type's closest competitor is the Airbus A330-200.cite webBoeing 767-400ERFlug RevueMarch 4, 2002http://www.flug-revue.rotor.com/Frtypen/FR767400.htmhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080513172529/http://www.flug-revue.rotor.com/Frtypen/FR767400.htmMay 13, 2008August 18, 2011
article.heading: Military and government
article.paragraph: Versions of the 767 serve in a number of military and government applications, with responsibilities ranging from airborne surveillance and refueling to cargo and VIP transport. Several military 767s have been derived from the 767-200ER,HarvnbBirtles199939–46.the longest-range version of the aircraft.

list.listitem: Airborne Surveillance Testbedthe Airborne Optical Adjunct (AOA) was modified from the prototype 767-200 for aUnited States Armyprogram, under a contract signed with theStrategic Air Commandin July 1984.cite webhttp://www.dtic.mil/cgi-bin/GetTRDoc?ADStrategic Defense Initiative Program: Status of Airborne Optical Adjunct and Terminal Imaging RadarJune 1986United States Government Accountability OfficeDecember 28, 20111, 9, 10Intended to evaluate the feasibility of using airborne optical sensors to detect and track hostileintercontinental ballistic missiles, the modified aircraft first flew on August 21, 1987.harvnbTaylor1989373–74.Alterations included a large "cupola" or hump which ran along the top of the aircraft from above the cockpit to just behind thetrailing edgeof the wings,and a pair of ventral fins below the rear fuselage.Inside the cupola was a suite of infrared seekers used for tracking theater ballistic missile launches.HarvnbBecher1999183–84.The aircraft was later renamed as the Airborne Surveillance Testbed (AST).harvnbNorrisWagner199687.Following the end of the AST program in 2002, the aircraft was retired for scrapping.Chism, Neal (March 20, 2006) "Correspondence: Save the First Boeing 767".Aviation Week & Space Technology, Volume 164, Issue 12, pp. 68.

link.part: alt=Side view of Japan military reconnaissance aircraft on airport runway, with dorsal mounted sensor pallet.

list.listitem: Boeing E-767E-767the Airborne Early Warning and Control (AWACS) platform for the Japan Self-Defense Forces; it is essentially theBoeing E-3 Sentrymission package on a 767-200ER platform.HarvnbBirtles199944–45.E-767 modifications, completed on 767-200ERs flown from the Everett factory toBoeing Defense, Space & SecurityBoeing Integrated Defense Systemsin Wichita, Kansas, include structural strengthening to accommodate a dorsal surveillance radar system, enginenacellealterations, as well as electrical and interior changes.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1994/1994%20-%202806.htmlBoeing poised to fly first 767 AWACSNorrisGuyFlight InternationalNovember 16, 1994August 30, 2011Japan is the operator of four E-767s. The first E-767s were delivered in March 1998.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1998/1998%20-%201967.htmlMilitary Aircraft Directory: BoeingJuly 29, 1998Flight InternationalDecember 9, 2011

Boeing KC-767KC-767 Advanced Tankerthe 767-200ER-based aerial tanker developed for the USAF KC-X tanker competition.It is an updated version of the KC-767, originally selected as the USAF's new tanker aircraft in 2003, designated KC-767A,cite webhttp://www.dtic.mil/whs/directives/corres/pdf/412015l.pdfDoD 4120-15L, Model Designation of Military Aerospace VehiclesUnited States Department of DefenseMay 12, 200430and then dropped amid conflict of interest allegations.The KC-767 Advanced Tanker is derived from studies for a longer-range cargo version of the 767-200ER,cite newsBorakDonnahttp://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/businesstechnology/2003568484_webtanker12.htmlBoeing unveils tanker for $40 billion dealSeattle TimesFebruary 12, 2007January 21, 2011cite webhttp://www.boeing.com/news/releases/2007/q1/070212b_nr.htmlBoeing Offers KC-767 Advanced Tanker to U.S. Air ForceBoeingFebruary 12, 20072015-07-04https://web.archive.org/web/20070214105112/http://www.boeing.com/news/releases/2007/q1/070212b_nr.html2007-02-14yesand features a fly-by-wireFlying Boomrefueling boom, aComputer stereo visionremote visionrefueling system, and a 767-400ER-based flight deck with LCD screens andhead-up displays.Boeing was awarded the KC-X contract to build a 767-based tanker, to be designatedBoeing KC-46KC-46A, in February 2011.

link.part: alt=A mostly-gray KC-767, with refueling probe extended, transferring fuel to a B-52 in the left-bottom hand corner.

list.listitem: Boeing KC-767#International programsKC-767 Tanker Transportthe 767-200ER-based aerial refueling platform operated by the Italian Air Force (Aeronautica Militare),cite webhttp://www.aeronautica.difesa.it/Mezzi/velivoliDotazione/Pagine/KC_767A.aspxIl portale dell'Aeronautica Militare - KC-767Adifesa.itApril 1, 2015and the Japan Self-Defense Forces.Modifications conducted by Boeing Integrated Defense Systems include the addition of a fly-by-wire refueling boom, strengthened flaps, and optional auxiliary fuel tanks, as well as structural reinforcement and modified avionics.All four KC-767Js ordered by Japan have been delivered.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/01/14/337167/picture-japan-receives-last-boeing-kc-767-tanker.htmlJapan receives last Boeing KC-767 tankerCraigHoyleFlight InternationalJanuary 14, 2010August 18, 2011The Aeronautica Militare received the first of its four KC-767As in January 2011.cite webKingtonTomhttp://www.defensenews.com/story.php?iItalian Air Force Receives 1st Tanker From BoeingDefense NewsJanuary 27, 2011January 28, 2011

Boeing KC-767#VariantsTanker conversions- the 767 MMTT or Multi-Mission Tanker Transport is a 767-200ER-based aircraft operated by theColombian Air Force(Fuerza Area Colombiana) and modified by Israel Aerospace Industries.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2010/09/06/347025/pictures-iai-tests-colombias-new-767-tanker.htmlIAI tests Colombia's new 767 tankerArieEgoziFlight InternationalJune 9, 2010September 2, 2011In 2013, theBrazilian Air Forceordered two 767-300ER tanker conversions from IAI for its KC-X2 program.cite webhttp://www.upi.com/Business_News/Security-Industry/2013/03/15/IAI-wins-Brazilian-KC-X-competition/UPI-98451363366032/%E2%89%A5Israel Aerospace Industries to work in Brazilian tank programUPI.comMarch 15, 2013June 2, 2013

article.heading: Undeveloped variants
767-400ERX
article.paragraph: Boeing offered the 767-400ERX, a longer-range version of the largest 767 model, for sale in 2000. Introduced along with theBoeing 747-8#Background747X, the type was to be powered by the 747X's engines, namely theEngine Alliance GP7000and theRolls-Royce TrentRolls-Royce Trent 600.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/2000/2000-1%20-%200364.htmlR-R offers Trent 600 for 767-400ERX and 747XFlight InternationalJulianMoxonNorris, GuyJuly 25, 2000August 19, 2011An increased range ofconvert6492nmikmwas specified.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/2000/2000%20-%200694.htmlLauda and Kenya eye heavy 767NorrisGuyFlight InternationalMarch 20, 2000August 19, 2010Kenya Airwaysprovisionally ordered three 767-400ERXs to supplement its 767 fleet, but after Boeing cancelled the type's development in 2001, switched the order to the 777-200ER.Cite newsWallaceJameshttp://www.seattlepi.com/default/article/Kenya-Airways-sticks-to-Boeing-1083149.phpKenya Airways sticks to BoeingSeattle Post-IntelligencerMarch 19, 2002June 7, 2011
article.heading: E-10 MC2A
article.paragraph: TheNorthrop Grumman E-10 MC2Awas to be a 767-400ER-based replacement for the USAF's 707-based E-3 Sentry AWACS,Northrop Grumman E-8 Joint STARS, andBoeing RC-135RC-135SIGINTaircraft.cite webTirpakJohnhttp://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/2007/October%202007/1007squeeze.aspxThe big squeezeAir Force MagazineOctober 2007August 30, 2011The E-10 MC2A would have included an all-new AWACS system, with a powerfulactive electronically scanned array(AESA) that was also capable of jamming enemy aircraft or missiles.cite webhttp://www.aviationweek.com/aw/jsp_includes/articlePrint.jsp?storyIDE-10 Radar Secretly Designed To Jam MissilesDavidFulghumAviation Week & Space TechnologyJuly 26, 2004August 19, 2011yeshttps://web.archive.org/20150216193318/http://www.aviationweek.com/aw/jsp_includes/articlePrint.jsp?storyID16 February 2015One 767-400ER aircraft was produced as a testbed for systems integration, but the program was terminated in January 2009 and the prototype sold to Bahrain as a VIP transport.

article.paragraph: The customers that have ordered the most 767s are FedEx, Delta Air Lines, All Nippon Airways and United Airlines.cite webAirline Seating Chartshttp://www.seatguru.com/Seat Guru by Trip AdvisorNovember 1, 2012Delta Air Lines is the largest customer, having received 117 aircraft.The Atlanta-based carrier is also the only customer to have ordered all passenger versions of the 767.cite webhttp://deltamuseum.org/M_ExhibitsEvents_SpiritofDelta.htmDelta Museum – Boeing B-767Delta Air Lines Air Transport Heritage MuseumAugust 18, 2011Its 100th example, a 767-400ER, was delivered in October 2000.cite webhttp://boeing.mediaroom.com/2000-10-23-Delta-Takes-Delivery-Of-Its-100th-New-Boeing-767-JetlinerDelta Takes Delivery Of Its 100th New Boeing 767 JetlinerBoeingOctober 23, 2000December 17, 2011FedEx confirmed that it had placed firm orders for 106 of the freighters for delivery between 2018 and 2023.cite newshttp://www.wsj.com/articles/fedex-to-buy-as-many-as-100-boeing-767-freighters-1437522505FedEx to Buy as Many as 100 Boeing 767 FreightersThe Wall Street Journal21 July 201521 July 2015United Airlines was the only carrier operating all versions of the 767 ER series (762ER, 763ER, and 764ER) as of November 2012.cite webStaffSeat GuruUnited Airlines Information and Aircrafthttp://www.seatguru.com/airlines/United_Airlines/information.phpSeat Guru by TripAdvisorNovember 1, 2012The largest cargo customer is UPS Airlines, having received 59 aircraft as of July 2015.

A total of 765 aircraft (all 767 variants) were in airline service in July 2015, with airline operatorsDelta Air Lines(95),UPS Airlines(59),American Airlines(56),All Nippon Airways(52),United Airlines(51),Japan Airlines(44),Air Canada(31), and others with fewer aircraft of the type.cite journalMorrisonMurdoFafardAntoine31 July 2015World Airliner Census 2015Flightglobal InsightFlight InternationalFlightglobal11 August 2015

article.heading: Incidents and accidents

preblock.preline: As of October 2015, the Boeing 767 has been in 44Aviation accidents and incidentsaviation occurrences,cite webhttp://aviation-safety.net/database/dblist.php?TypeBoeing 767 occurrencesAviation Safety NetworkSeptember 27, 2015September 27, 2015including 15Hull losshull-loss accidents.cite webhttp://aviation-safety.net/database/dblist.php?fieldBoeing 767 hull-lossesAviation Safety NetworkSeptember 27, 2015September 27, 2015Six fatal crashes, including threeAircraft hijackinghijackings, have resulted in a total of 851 occupant fatalities.cite webhttp://aviation-safety.net/database/type/type-stat.php?typeBoeing 767 StatisticsAviation Safety NetworkSeptember 27, 2015September 27, 2015The airliner's first fatal crash,Lauda Air Flight 004, occurred near Bangkok on May 26, 1991, following the in-flight deployment of the left enginethrust reverseron a 767-300ER; none of the 223 aboard survived; as a result of this accident all 767 thrust reversers were deactivated until a redesign was implemented.Cite newsJamesBarryBarry JamesU.S. Orders Thrust Reversers Deactivated on 767sThe New York TimesAugust 17, 1991http://www.nytimes.com/1991/08/17/news/17iht-thru.htmlAugust 19, 2011Investigators determined that an electronically controlled valve, common to late-model Boeing aircraft, was to blame.cite webhttp://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?dateAir Disasters: Critics Question FAA's ResponseSeattle TimesByronAcohidoSeptember 1, 1991December 26, 2011A new locking device was installed on all affected jetliners, including 767s.cite webhttp://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?dateNew Locks Installed For Boeing ReversersSeattle TimesPollyLaneMay 26, 1992December 26, 2011On October 31, 1999,EgyptAir Flight 990, a 767-300ER, crashed offNantucket Island, Massachusetts, ininternational waterskilling all 217 people on board.cite webAccident descriptionAviation Safety NetworkJuly 27, 2004http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?idJanuary 19, 2011The U.S.National Transportation Safety Board(NTSB) determined the probable cause to be due to a deliberate action by the first officer; Egypt disputed this conclusion.cite newsEllisonMichaelUS and Egypt split on fatal plane crashhttp://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2000/jun/09/egyptaircrash.usaAugust 18, 2011The GuardianJune 9, 2000On April 15, 2002,Air China Flight 129, a 767-200ER,controlled flight into terraincrashed into a hillamid inclement weather while trying to land atGimhae International AirportinBusan, South Korea. The crash resulted in the death of 129 of the 166 people on board, and the cause was attributed topilot error.cite webAccident descriptionAviation Safety NetworkAugust 27, 2005http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?idJanuary 19, 2011

link.part: The "Gimli Glider" parked atMojave Air and Space Portin February 2008
alt=Side view of a parked Air Canada twin-engine jet in the desert, with stairs mounted next to the aircraft's forward door.

article.paragraph: An early 767 incident was survived by all on board. On July 23, 1983,Gimli GliderAir Canada Flight 143, a 767-200, ran out of fuel in-flight and had to glide with both engines out for almostconvert43nmikmto an emergency landing atGimli, Manitoba. The pilots used the aircraft's ram air turbine to power the hydraulic systems for aerodynamic control. There were no fatalities and only minor injuries. This aircraft was nicknamed "Gimli Glider" after the airport at which it landed. The aircraft, registered C-GAUN, continued flying for Air Canada until its retirement in January 2008. The aircraft was subsequently scrapped in 2008.cite newshttp://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/storied-gimli-glider-on-final-approach/article666567/Storied 'Gimli Glider' on final approachGlobe and MailJanuary 24, 2008August 18, 2011

The 767 has been involved in six hijackings, three resulting in loss of life,for a combined total of 282 occupant fatalities.On November 23, 1996,Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961, a 767-200ER, was hijacked and crash-landed in theIndian Oceannear theComoros Islandsafter running out of fuel, killing 125 out of the 175 persons onboard;cite webhttp://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?idHijacking descriptionAviation Safety NetworkMarch 7, 2009January 19, 2011survivors have been rare among instances of land-based aircraft ditching on water.cite webhttp://edition.cnn.com/2009/US/01/16/air.crash.ditching/index.htmlPrevious jet ditchings yielded survival lessonsCNNLendon, BradJanuary 16, 2009February 5, 2012cite webhttp://articles.nydailynews.com/2009-01-15/local/17913592_1_plane-st-maarten-pilotA very rare happy ending in Hudson River plane crashNew York Daily NewsDaveGoldinerJanuary 15, 2009August 19, 2011Two 767s were involved in theSeptember 11 attackson theWorld Trade Center (1973-2001)World Trade Centerin 2001, resulting in the collapse of its two main towers.American Airlines Flight 11, a 767-200ER, crashed into the north tower, killing all 92 people on board, andUnited Airlines Flight 175, a 767-200, crashed into the south tower, with the death of all 65 on board. In addition, more than 2,600 people were killed in the towers or on the ground.cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/23/world/threats-responses-excerpts-report-sept-11-commission-unity-purpose.html?pagewantedThreats and Responses; Excerpts from the Report of the Sept. 11 Commission: 'A Unity of Purpose'The New York TimesJuly 23, 2004January 22, 2011A foiled2001 shoe bomb plotinvolving an American Airlines 767-300ER resulted in passengers being required to remove their shoes for scanning at U.S. security checkpoints.cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/2003/01/31/us/threats-responses-bomb-plot-unrepentant-shoe-bomber-given-life-sentence-for.html?pagewantedThreats and Responses: The Bomb Plot: Unrepentant Shoe Bomber Is Given a Life SentenceBelluckPamJanuary 31, 2003The New York TimesAugust 19, 2011cite webhttp://www.tsa.gov/travelers/airtravel/screening/index.shtmTSA Travel AssistantUnited States Transportation Security AdministrationSeptember 26, 2006January 20, 2011

On November 1, 2011,LOT Polish Airlines Flight 16, a 767-300ER, safely landed atWarsaw Frederic Chopin AirportinWarsaw, Polandafter a mechanical failure of the landing gear forced an emergency landing with the landing gear up. There were no injuries, but the aircraft involved was damaged and subsequently written off.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/warsaw-airport-still-closed-after-lot-gear-up-landing-364195/Warsaw Airport still closed after LOT gear-up landingFlight InternationalNovember 2, 2011December 9, 2011cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/lot-767-gear-up-crash-probe-advises-checklist-changes-378418/LOT 767 gear-up crash probe advises checklist changes -DavidKaminski-MorrowFlight InternationalNovember 1, 2012August 20, 2014At the time of the incident, aviation analysts speculated that it may have been the first instance of a complete landing gear failure in the 767's service history.cite webhttp://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1111/01/ebo.01.htmlCNN Transcript - Erin Burnett OutFrontCNNNovember 1, 2011December 26, 2011Subsequent investigation however determined that while a damaged hose had disabled the aircraft's primary landing gear extension system, an otherwise functional backup system was inoperative due to an accidentally deactivatedcircuit breaker.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/circuit-breaker-at-heart-of-lot-767-gear-up-landing-probe-365584/Circuit-breaker at heart of LOT 767 gear-up landing probeFlight InternationalKaminski-MorrowDavidDecember 5, 2011December 26, 2011

In January 2014, the U.S.Federal Aviation Administrationissued a directive that ordered inspections of the elevators on more than 400 767s beginning in March 2014; the focus is onfastenersand other parts that can fail and cause the elevators to jam. The issue was first identified in 2000 and has been the subject of several Boeing service bulletins. The inspections and repairs are required to be completed within six years.Pasztor, Andy."FAA orders safety checks on Boeing 767s". Wall Street Journal, January 27, 2014, p. B3.
article.heading: Retirement and display

link.part: "The Spirit of Delta" at theDelta Heritage MuseumDelta Air Lines Air Transport Heritage Museum
alt=Side view of a parked Delta Air Lines twin-engine jet in hangar, with stairs mounted next to the aircraft's forward door.

article.paragraph: As new 767s roll off the assembly line, older models have been retired and scrapped. One complete aircraft is known to have been retained for exhibition, specifically N102DA, the first 767-200 to operate for Delta Air Lines and the twelfth example built.HarvnbBirtles199955, 116.The exhibition aircraft, named "The Spirit of Delta" by the employees who helped purchase it in 1982, underwent restoration at theDelta Heritage MuseumDelta Air Lines Air Transport Heritage Museumin Atlanta, Georgia.cite webhttp://deltamuseum.org/M_ExhibitsEvents_SpiritofDelta.htmDecember 15, 1982: A Special Day for Delta Air LinesDelta Air Lines Air Transport Heritage MuseumMay 7, 2009The restoration was completed in 2010.Featuring the original delivered interior as well as historical displays, the aircraft is viewable by visitors (self-guided) daily, during the museum's operating hours.cite webhttp://blog.seattlepi.com/airlinereporter/2010/10/13/the-spirit-of-delta-air-lines-the-gift-of-a-boeing-767/The Spirit of Delta Air Lines: The gift of a Boeing 767Seattle Post-IntelligencerJanuary 19, 2011October 13, 2010Parker BrownDavidHangar renovations, begun in June 2013, are now complete, and the museum is accessible on a daily basis.cite webhttp://takingoff.delta.com/post/59490549158/discover-delta-protecting-the-spirit-of-deltaProtecting "The Spirit of Delta"...Delta Air LinesNovember 29, 2013

In 2005, four retired American Airlines 767-200s were dismantled for parts in Roswell, New Mexico, and their nose sections removed intact for collector or film use.cite webhttp://www.scrogginsaviation.com/Airways767SAI.htmlScroggins Aviation Aircraft DismantlingScroggins Aviation2011August 17, 2011yeshttps://web.archive.org/web/20090207120653/http://scrogginsaviation.com/Airways767SAI.htmlFebruary 7, 2009Of these four aircraft, the cockpit of N301AA, the eighth 767 built and the first of its type delivered to American Airlines, was transported to Victorville, California, to be restored for museum display."Scroggins Aviation Boeing 767 cockpit". Scroggins Aviation. 2011. Retrieved August 17, 2011.As of 2013, the cockpit section of N301AA is housed at the interim museum location of the American Museum of Aviation, a nonprofit organization in Las Vegas, Nevada, along with a display of American Airlines photographs.cite webhttp://www.americanmuseumofaviation.org/exhibits/Exhibits #124; American Museum of AviationAmerican Museum of Aviation2013November 29, 2013Clear
